data.title: Install code-insiders in PATH should not override code
data.body: When using code-insiders and selecting "Install code-insiders in PATH", it also overrides the code command. I would like to have both commands so I can choose whether to use insiders or not.

data.title: I lost "unused imports" warning
data.body: I am selfhosting with gulp-tsb running in VS Code and I am no longer seeing warnings for unused imports.

data.title: TypeScript errors are multiline but do not surface in the editor or problems view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am starting to selfhost on running the gulp tsb task in the workbench. Since errors are multi line, I am missing important information I had before:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/15890026/ea6aea2e-2d6d-11e6-8959-1beec6329c80.png)

Neither are the multi line errors showing up in the hover in the editor nor are they showing up in the problems view.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/15890047/13c8e6e6-2d6e-11e6-9885-f8989c8a3f3b.png)

Marking as important because this makes my selfhost unusable with this setup.

Following is the link- 
https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Shan.code-settings-sync

When i try to install extension via  VS Code Quick Open (Ctrl+P) and paste `ext install code-settings-sync` and hit enter. 
My extension doesnt come at first and selected

But when i write `ext install visualcode-settings-sync` it works.

Please correct the ext install name in the page there is some diflict

data.title: editor becomes unresponsive all the time since last update
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
2. Update to latest version

I just updated my Visual Studio Code to the latest version. Congratulations, since then it is unresponsive all the time. I can work for a few seconds, then I hit a key, it freezes and can only be solved by killing the process through task manager...
It was running nice and smooth before the latest update, which I got today. Sadly I can't work like this and need a reliable editor, so I have to go back to use something else now.

Good luck.

data.title: Can't expand reference in Find All References
data.body:
![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/15888496/5f49c6d2-2d67-11e6-9081-cfbb0af31225.gif)

Sorry for the large steps...
- `cd vscode`
- `git remote add joao https://github.com/joaomoreno/vscode.git`
- `git fetch joao`
- `git checkout ae0f60e9469942097769b25e21ad597ba2db85aa`
- Open that folder in Code
- Open `src/vs/platform/telemetry/common/telemetry.ts`
- Find All References of `isOptedIn` in line 36.

data.title: Refactaring Hex RGB to Basic color name
data.body:
It is very little change.
I use 16 basic color.(ex. red, blue) to improving readability of css code.
Reference (https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-color/#html4)

But I didn't touch css file that in test directory or example.css.
And changed css code already used basic color names.

data.title: The OS magnifier can't follow the text input cursor in editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.1
- OS Version:windows7

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Press Win + R shortcut key to open the "Run Dialog", and input "magnify" to open the magnifier tool in the windows system. Then setting the magnifier to follow mouse pointer, follow keyboard focus, and follow text input cursor. 
2.  Open vscode, new a blank document, input some long text. You will find that the magnifier can't follow the text input cursor in editor.

**Thanks for this great code editor! But my eyesight is bad, magnifier is needed. I know the input cursor is just a simulated one using html+css+js, is there any way to make it can be followed by the OS magnifier when input in the editor?**

data.title: Command for keybindings to input specific characters (like utf-8)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: any ?
- OS Version: Mac OSX

This is not really a bug ; is there a command that would allow me to define a keyboard shortcut that would enter specific text ?

The reason is I want to use a utf-8 character in my text that my keyboard can't produce (ᐅ to be exact). I had it bound on ctrl+shift+o in Sublime text thanks to a command "insert" that takes `"args": {"characters": "ᐅ"}` in the key bindings.

It seems there is no such command. Is there another way ? Should this command be created ?

data.title: Improve update experience

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
For me the daily (or even hourly) update notification in the insiders channel is not adding any value. I would like to just ditch this message when you are on the insiders channel. Depending on the platform, this has some consequences:

**Mac**: best experience, when you restart you just get the update. 

**Windows**: when you restart, the installer runs to do the update. OK if you expect it, otherwise might be confusing so we have to educate users.

**Linux**: since we do not have auto update, we could just hide the message and the user can go to the package manager to do the update when he wants.

@Microsoft/vscode ping for opinions.

data.title: Multiple monitors: git password prompt

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Commit
2. Click Synchronize Changes

github password prompt will appear on the secondary monitor under all others windows. If there is anything in fullscreen on the secondary monitor you won't even notice that it has appeared.

data.title: Stacks - Debugger frequently covers actionable editor buttons requiring editor resize
data.body:
This was always an issue but with more actionable buttons in the new editors like the overflow menu, it is more of an issue now.
- VSCode Version: 1.3 insider
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an editor on the left
2. Run a program

![](http://i.imgur.com/EwUE5YG.png)

I'm not sure what the solution is here. Maybe a small handle on either side of the debugger that allows us to drag the debugger out of the way? Maybe putting the debugger in the completely blank header of the debug panel?

![](http://i.imgur.com/TAI9o91.png)

data.title: Monaco API Request : Ship standalone languages
data.body:
Please still ship standalone languages in monaco :heart: 

Specifically talking about this commit : https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/3268ae1e5e4d6f0d510bb34ded4a2705e859ccc1 

They actually work quite nicely e.g. you can see a c# file here in [alm](http://alm.tools/): 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/874898/15882448/e9787654-2d81-11e6-8845-4846ecbc4f0e.png)

Indeed they might not be as good as the textmate languages, but they are good enough for an editor that isn't focused on these other languages but still allows you to make quick edits (or just read) these.

Thanks for a great editor component :rose:

data.title: [css] Support 8 (#RRGGBBAA) and 4 (#RGBA) value hex colors
Monaco API request : Create a custom action
data.body:
I have bunch of custom editor actions in [alm.tools](http://alm.tools/) e.g. HTML to TSX https://basarat.gitbooks.io/alm/content/features/html-to-tsx.html. 

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/alm-tools/alm-tools.github.io/master/screens/htmlToTsx.gif)

As you know I'm in the process of migrating from codemirror to monaco https://github.com/alm-tools/alm/pull/121 and need a way to plug in custom editor actions. 

As far as I can see such a mechanism isn't exported. Would be great if it could be exported :rose:

data.title: PPA for Ubuntu?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu Xenial

Manual install via .deb feels kinda 1990's... a lot like Windows! ;)
Can MS register a Launchpad account and host an official MS PPA, which would contain vscode, and potentially other software too?
Other people already have unofficial PPA's for vscode to solve this inconvenience, but it never feels good getting software from unknown sources... MS should take ownership of the common distribution channels.

data.title: Support Visual Studio's 'Concord' debug engine in windows?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows

Feature Request:

Please support Visual Studio's Concord debug engine? Using GDB to debug local windows apps is pretty awkward. I think everyone agrees; Visual Studio has the best debugger in the world, and it's available to everyone via the free community edition.

data.title: Support WinDBG as debugengine for windows?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows

Feature Request:

Please support WinDBG as Windows debug engine. Using GDB to debug local windows apps is pretty awkward.

data.title: Linux integrated terminal mouse-wheel scrolling problems
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu Xenial - .deb install

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the integrated terminal
2. Do something that overpopulates the window with a lot of output (ie, 'make', or a long 'ls')
3. Try and scroll using the mouse wheel

In windows, the terminal scrolls smoothly as expected.
On linux, the terminal scrolling is very jerky, unresponsive, and occasionally it scrolls horizontally instead of vertically, and the terminal display gets stuck scrolled to the right with the left-hand text cut off/not-visible.

Expect: Scrolling the terminal on linux should be smooth, and work properly.

data.title: Can't Create a folder that has the same name as a file with no extension.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  version 1.2.0
  shell 0.47.6
- OS Version:Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
In my use case i needed to move my dockefile to a folder called dockerfile for docker hub. When i treid this i get a error.  The issue i believe is that this file doesn't have a file type and it can't distinguish if its a folder or not. Probably failry big edge case and not a critical bug. 
1. Create a file with no extension. mine is called dockerfile
2. right click on the site and select add new folder
3. type in dockerfile
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3301804/15879296/b2c3d248-2cd7-11e6-8286-eab710bbbcf0.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3301804/15879300/b6546a58-2cd7-11e6-9768-1e6f113f25bc.png)

data.title: Insiders can't start Go debug session: "Cannot find Delve debugger."
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.3.0-insider 2016-06-07T14:59:54.411Z
- OS Version: OSX El Capitian

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set up a Go project for debugging.
2. Try to start debugging.
3. Error pops up at the top of the screen:  

```
Failed to continue: Cannot find Delve debugger. Ensure it is in your `GOPATH/bin` or `PATH`.
```

With a prompt to edit my launch.json.

This happened in my Go projects after today's update. Did launch.json change? I can't find the Insiders nightlies release notes...
